newsitem.title: MOROCCO: Moroccan blue chips pull down bourse index.
newsitem.headline: Moroccan blue chips pull down bourse index.

text.p: The Casablanca bourse index dropped slightly on Thursday, pulled down mainly by market blue chips, including Societe Nationale d'Investissement and Samir refinery, traders said.
The all share index closed at 430.10 points, down 0.27 percent on the previous session.
The biggest fall was registered by SNI which lost eight dirhams in one session to close at 592 dirhams.
Banque Commerciale du Maroc lost five dirhams to close at 680 dirhams.
BCM is the bourse's largest stock which has a market capitalisation of more than 9.2 billion dirhams.
Morocco's main oil refinery, Samir lost three dirhams to close at one of its lowest levels, 252 dirhams.

This coincided with announcement of its half-year results, which showed a drop of 3.9 percent in turnover to 3.210 billion dirhams ($368.9 million) in the first half of the year compared with the same period in 1995.
Earlier this year, the government floated 30 percent of the refinery on the Casablanca bourse at 243 dirhams a share.
Wafabank, one of the market blue chips, made no change for the second consecutive session and closed at 505 dirhams.
ONA Group, Morocco's largest private group and one of the main market capitalisation companies, remained also unchanged at 450 dirhams.
First tranche of privatisation bonds, which were issued in January, traded at 1,132 dirhams, up eight dirhams on Wednesday's session.
The second tranche of the bonds, which was issued in May, remained unchanged at 1,076 dirhams.
Both bonds are negotiable on the market or can be converted into equity in future privatisations.
The bourse volume on the official market was 35.4 million up from 29.6 millionn Wednesday.
